INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Japan and West Germany must act to emulate America and they need the ''gumption'' to take unpleasant economic medicine for the benefit of a debt-burdened and slow-growing world economy, President Reagan told the annual meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. Page A1 A ban on imports from Iran, most of which are oil, was voted by the Senate without dissent. The largely symbolic measure reflected frustration over the situation in the Persian Gulf. A1 New U.S. aid to Pakistan was halted by Congress until the Reagan Administration and legislators resolve the issue of Pakistan's nuclear development program. A waiver of a U.S. law that would have prohibited all aid expires today. A1 Mikhail S. Gorbachev quelled speculation about his physical and political health by reappearing at the Kremlin after a 52-day absence from public view. Mr. Gorbachev was shown on television looking tanned, rested and robust. A1 South Korea's opposition deadlocked as its two dominant leaders, Kim Young Sam and Kim Dae Jung, failed to show a willingness to compromise on which of them should be their party's presidential candidate. A3 Neil Kinnock urged the Labor Party in England to examine its Socialist economic principles in light of the new ''realities'' brought about by nine years of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's policies. A14 French fortunetellers are in demand to tell who will be the next President, reflecting a genuine uncertainty about the race. President Francois Mitterrand leads in the opinion polls. Bork's confirmation has erupted, following the majority leader's a suggestion that the Senate vote without a recommendation from the Judiciary Committee. A1 Tax code changes to raise revenues would be considered by the Reagan Administration in an effort to avoid an estimated $23 billion in automatic budget cuts, said the director of management and budget, James C. Miller 3d. A28 Victor Posner pleaded no contest in Miami to charges of evading more than $1.2 million in Federal income taxes by inflating the value of land donated to a Miami Bible college. D1 The Rev. Pat Robertson will sever his ties to the religious broadcasting empire he has led for 27 years. Mr. Robertson, who plans to announce his candidacy for President, is also resigning as a Southern Baptist minister. A20 Women at high risk of AIDS infection are well-informed about the disease but few change their behavior, experts meeting in Maryland at a federally sponsored conference on AIDS and women said. A18 Adults are replacing children as the major consumers of comic books. Publishers are trying to satisfy adult tastes by marrying off some characters, aging others and offering slicker editions. A1 American chefs are endorsing products as diverse as cooking equipment and credit cards as they discover that culinary celebrity can be easily converted into the coin of the realm. REGIONAL B1-3 A law that would give patients in New York the ironclad right to authorize other people to make life-and-death decisions about their medical treatment was proposed by Governor Cuomo's Task Force on Life and the Law. A1 The region's deer have multiplied to their highest level in centuries, posing serious, as well as comical, problems for motorists, farmers and suburban homeowners. Wildlife officials say many deer are being killed by cars. B1 The Museum of the American Indian, which New York officials have worked to keep in New York City, would move to Washington under a bill proposed by Senator Daniel K. Inouye, chairman of the Select Committee on Indian Affairs. B3 A seminary has rejected a proposal to build a luxury condominium tower on its Morningside Heights campus. Financially pressed Union Theological Seminary opted instead to raise money by selling or leasing an off-campus residence hall. B3 New York's incinerator ash will not be classified as hazardous waste, the State Environmental Commissioner said, despite test results that show most of it exceeded Federal limits for hazardous waste. B1 The Dreyfus Corporation may move its 1,200-employee headquarters and back-office operations out of New York City, after the breakdown of negotiations between the company and the city, city officials said. B1 Work rules for firefighters that prevent them from inspecting buildings in ''inclement weather'' are under attack by New York City officials in negotiations on a new contract with the firefighters' union.
